message_1:
A company is testing three different types of packaging designs to see which one keeps their product freshest for the longest amount of time. They randomly choose 24 boxes of their product and divide them equally between the three packaging designs. After 5 days they open the boxes and record the freshness for each design. The scores are as follows:

Design 1: 15, 13, 14, 16, 15, 12
Design 2: 13, 14, 16, 11, 10, 12
Design 3: 14, 15, 17, 13, 12, 11

Find the mean, median, mode, and standard deviation for each of the designs. Which design appears to be the best?
message_2:
First, let's find the mean, median, and mode for each design:

Design 1:
Mean: (15+13+14+16+15+12)/6 = 85/6 = 14.17
Median: (14+15)/2 = 14.5
Mode: 15

Design 2:
Mean: (13+14+16+11+10+12)/6 = 76/6 = 12.67
Median: (12+13)/2 = 12.5
Mode: None (all values occur only once)

Design 3:
Mean: (14+15+17+13+12+11)/6 = 82/6 = 13.67
Median: (13+14)/2 = 13.5
Mode: None (all values occur only once)

Now, let's find the standard deviation for each design:

Design 1:
Variance: [(15-14.17)^2 + (13-14.17)^2 + (14-14.17)^2 + (16-14.17)^2 + (15-14.17)^2 + (12-14.17)^2]/(6-1) = 7.97
Standard Deviation: √7.97 ≈ 2.82

Design 2:
Variance: [(13-12.67)^2 + (14-12.67)^2 + (16-12.67)^2 + (11-12.67)^2 + (10-12.67)^2 + (12-12.67)^2]/(6-1) = 6.27
Standard Deviation: √6.27 ≈ 2.50

Design 3:
Variance: [(14-13.67)^2 + (15-13.67)^2 + (17-13.67)^2 + (13-13.67)^2 + (12-13.67)^2 + (11-13.67)^2]/(6-1) = 7.47
Standard Deviation: √7.47 ≈ 2.73

Based on the mean, median, mode, and standard deviation, Design 1 appears to be the best as it has the highest mean and median freshness scores, a mode, and a relatively low standard deviation.
